Class HardwareStore

  • java.lang.Object
    • HardwareStore

  • public class HardwareStore
extends java.lang.Object
    This class is used to represent a database interface for a list of item's. It using a plain-text file "database.txt" to store and write item objects in readable text form. It contains an ArrayList called itemList to store the database in a runtime friendly data structure. The itemList is written to "database.txt" at the end of the HardwareStore object's life by calling writeDatabase(). This class also provides methods for adding, removing, and searching for items in the list.
    Author:
    Junye Wen

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      HardwareStore()
      This constructor creates an empty ArrayList and then calls the readDatabase() method to populate items previously stored.

      • progressTransaction

        public void progressTransaction(java.lang.String itemId,
                                int saleQuantity,
                                int customerId,
                                int employeeId,
                                int itemIndex)
        This method will add a transaction to the list, and remove the quantity for the target item.
        Parameters:
        itemId - a String representing the ID of item
        saleQuantity - an int of the quantity
        customerId - an int representing the ID of customer
        employeeId - an int representing the ID of employee
        itemIndex - an int representing the index of item in the list, used to reduce the quantity.

      • readDatabase

        public void readDatabase()
                  throws java.io.IOException
        The method opens the database file and initializes the itemList, userList, transactionList and the userIdCounter with their contents. If no such file exists, then one is created. The contents of the file are "loaded" into the itemList ArrayList in no particular order. The file is then closed during the duration of the program until writeDatabase() is called.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • removeItem

        public void removeItem(int itemIndex)
        This method can be used to remove a item in the Arraylist of items.
        Parameters:
        itemIndex - an int that represents the Index of the item in the list that to be removed.

      • removeQuantity

        public void removeQuantity(int itemIndex,
                           int quantity)
        Removes a certain quantity of the given item index. Preconditions: 1. Item exists. 2. Quantity to remove smaller than current quantity.
        Parameters:
        itemIndex - the index of the item in the itemList
        quantity - the quantity to remove

      • sortItemList

        public static void sortItemList()
        This method will sort the item list, based on the item ID.

      • sortUserList

        public static void sortUserList()
        This method will sort the user list, based on the user ID.

      • writeDatabase

        public void writeDatabase()
                   throws java.io.IOException
        This method opens the database file and overwrites it with a serialized representation of all the items in the itemList, all users in the userList, all transactions in the transactionList, and the userIdCounter. This should be the last method to be called before exiting the program.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
